titleStmt.title: Body-centered cubic high-entropy alloys: From processing to underlying deformation mechanisms

affiliation.orgName: Paris-East Institute of Chemistry and Materials (ICMPE)
UMR7182, Metals and Ceramics with Controlled Microstructures (MCMC)

analytic.title: Body-centered cubic high-entropy alloys: From processing to underlying deformation mechanisms

biblStruct.note: Received 14 March 2018; Received in revised form 12 July 2018; Accepted 12 July 2018

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: High-entropy alloys BCC Processing Mechanical properties Deformation mechanisms

div.p: In 14 years, high entropy alloys (HEAs) have been among the most studied materials in the metallurgical field. The concept is attractive and offers the possibility to explore new materials and to revisit the basic concepts of metallurgy. Moreover, HEAs show interesting combinations of properties which are composition dependent and hence are related to the alloy structure. Among the studied HEAs, those with body-centered cubic (BCC) systems are particularly interesting as they mainly retain attractive mechanical properties and are candidates for structural applications under extreme conditions. The present manuscript provides an overview on single phase BCC high-entropy alloys with disordered structure. Analysis of the existing data from the available literature is performed and trends relative to the processing of such materials, but also to the mechanical behavior and underlying deformation mechanisms, are given, along with some critical view points and prospects.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: One of the purposes of materials design is to directly facilitate their use or enhance their properties (physical, chemical, mechanical, etc.) in order to keep developing the frontiers of human activity even when its level becomes increasingly huge compared to the capacity of the Earth. To fulfill the demand for materials with better performances, a breakthrough is needed and should be based on new material concepts. As recently discussed by Saada and Dirras [1], the general principles underlying the processing of high strength and ductile metallic materials have been clarified since the beginning of the development of dislocation theory. The ductility necessitates a reasonable mobility of the dislocations, while strengthening is related to the building of obstacles restricting their propagation: dislocations, solute atoms, second phase inclusions and grain boundaries. These obstacles are introduced by alloying in the case of structural hardening; by plastic flow in the case of strain hardening; and by grain size refinement as evidenced by the Hall-Petch relation [2][3][4][5]. These concepts have been successfully applied in pure metals and alloys within the framework of classical metallurgy. However, conventional metallurgy has hitherto been unable to produce materials to satisfy both high strength and ductility, which are quite antagonist concepts. Indeed, strengthening via the design of alloys with increasing the concentration of alloying elements often leads to formation of intermetallic phases, which in turn increases the brittleness of the alloys so fabricated.

Due to the increasingly demanding performance required for structural materials, new strategies and concepts must be explored. Among all the proposed innovative concepts, the alloying design based on multi-principal elements (as opposed to conventional diluted alloys) emerges as a powerful strategy to develop new materials with enhanced properties. These multiple components solid solution alloys defined originally as high-entropy alloys (HEAs) by Yeh et al. [6], have been attracting extensive attention due to their unique compositions, microstructures and good mechanical properties, such as high strength, high ductility and high fracture toughness in a large temperature range [7][8][9]. As initially proposed, HEAs are typically composed of at least five principal elements with equiatomic or near-equiatomic ratios and prone to form simple solid solutions, initially thought to be induced by high mixing configurational entropy, which reduces the Gibbs free energy. Further developments show that it is not a universal criterion. Indeed, depending on their actual composition, the HEAs may present complex microstructures which affect the link between the parameters of thermomechanical treatments and their deformation mechanisms in a complex and still unclear way [10][11][12].

To date two main HEAs families are reported in the literature: (i) alloys based on 3d transition metals (Co, Cr, Cu, Fe, Mn, Ni), with possible additions of Al and other elements, which have been studied most comprehensively. This family generally forms solid solutions crystallizing in a simple face centered cubic (FCC) structure and also ordered structures with more or less significant additions of Al, and (ii) the refractory HEA (RHEAs) alloy systems, which are composed mainly of refractory elements such as Cr, Hf, Mo, Nb, Ta, V, W, and Zr (see for instance those developed by Senkov et al. [13][14][15][16][17]). Their major phase is cubic with a body-centered cubic (BCC) (or sometimes B2) structure. While the FCC HEA family has been extensively investigated, a limited (but growing) number of studies deal with the BCC counterpart. For the latter, when available, the majority of the investigations so far published deals with their processing and the macroscopic mechanical behavior evaluation.

Departing from this usual approach, in a recent report by Gorsse et al. [18], a material database covering the main mechanical properties of HEAs and complex concentrated alloys has been developed. Their performance for light weight structures and high temperature structural applications have been displayed. Of particular interest, some attractive combination of properties of refractory metal HEAs and complex concentrated alloys have been uncovered: almost all these alloys have specific strength values noticeably higher than those for commercial refractory alloys and they can compete with Ti alloys, Ni alloys, and even steels. Furthermore the smart analysis by Gorsse et al. of the different HEAs supporting extreme (mechanical) conditions reveals that most of the potential systems are often multi-phase materials based on refractory elements with at least one disordered BCC phase (Fig. 6c of [18]). In that context, in-depth analysis of the underlying thermodynamics, and deformation mechanisms in BCC HEAs is worth uncovering. This seems to be a necessary step, toward the design of more efficient materials for a wide range of structural applications and functions, in industrial fields such as transportation, nuclear, defense, chemistry, biomedical, etc. Despite the interest for them especially for potential high temperature applications, multiphase (refractory) HEAs will not be considered in the review. Consequently, only BCC single solid solution HEAs with equiatomic and near-equiatomic proportions are addressed.

The aim of the present work is thus to bring a critical but constructive view based on the main studies published so far on BCC HEAs with (disordered) single-phase microstructures. Among all the studied HEAs, > 70 BCC solid solutions have been experimentally identified. Our analysisnot intended to be exhaustive (the reader will find more details in a recent review [19])will give general trends and will be focused on four main points: first, some considerations relative to the formation of single-phase BCC HEAs will be discussed; second, we shall attempt to describe the current fabrication methods for such materials; in the third part, the analysis of their macroscopic mechanical properties will be presented, through various loading conditions in the quasi-static and the dynamic regimes. Underlying deformation mechanisms will be approached in the fourth part.

div.head: General considerations
div.p: Since the emergence of the new breakthrough alloying concept, the great majority of studies was related to the formation conditions of materials with presence of compositionally complex solid solutions. From the thermodynamic point of view and following the first developed approach, solid solutions were supposed to form in systems for which the mixing (configurational) entropy is high enough to counterbalance the effects of mixing enthalpy and also avoid segregation phenomena and possible formation of (supposed brittle) ordered intermetallic phases [20]. Equimolar or near-equimolar alloy compositions with more than five elements have long been considered thanks to the large configurational entropy attained by such systems but with various degrees of success. However, these considerations lead to an almost unlimited number of potential systems "prone" to the formation of simple solid solutions while in practice many of these systems have multiple phases. It has been then tempting to define rules/criteria able to guide the prediction of alloy compositions with concentrated elements giving rise to the formation of simple solid solutions. Basically these criteria derive from the extrapolation of the Hume-Rothery rules and reflect the structural and chemical compatibility of alloying elements. More than ten criteria are actually reported in literature with more or less complex approaches [21][22][23][24][25][26][27]. Initially the most commonly used parameters have been related to accessible quantities including configurational mixing entropy ΔS mix , mixing enthalpy ΔH mix based on atomic pair enthalpy [28], atomic size difference δ and the Ω parameter reflecting the ratio between entropy and enthalpy contributions of a given system at melting temperature T m . Even if it was first very excited to define zones of existence for single phase materials [21], a posteriori analysis of these criteria encourage to a great caution as they could not represent sufficient requirements to form single solid solutions. Some interesting features were evidenced with these parameters as it was pointed out for the Cantor system (CoCrFeNiMn) and the formation of an ideal solid solution [29]. The deficiencies of such empirical criteria have been discussed recently [30]. Therefore Miracle and Senkov [31], and recently Gao et al. [30] suggest that the effectiveness of the empirical parameters is generally limited to a restricted number of cases and is finally reduced to the only separation between crystalline single phase materials and amorphous ones especially if one considers the evolution of mixing enthalpy ΔH mix with δ [30,31]. From experimental results, it seems fairly clear that unique solid solutions may not form if concomitantly +5 kJ•mol -1 < ΔH mix < -16 kJ•mol -1 and δ > 6.1% [30]. However even though some parameters have been refined in the past few years and new approaches have appeared [32], current criteria do not produce a clear separation between solid solutions and multi-phase materials. The reason is that approximations of the quantities of interest, such as atomic radii and melting temperatures of concentrated alloys, are wrongly based on mixing laws or thermodynamic criteria: in that way, and even if recent efforts have been made [33], the calculation of mixing entropy has often been limited to the configurational part, non-configurational contributions (vibrational, magnetic…) being ignored or neglected [29,34]; in the case of the mixing enthalpy, atomic pair energies reached from the Miedena's model only give mean enthalpies at the liquid state, and the predictive character of such parameter (as cast materials with non-equilibrium microstructures, mainly [31]). Coupled approaches seem essential to consider thermodynamics of such complex systems. In that sense, the coupling between first principles calculations and CALPHAD modeling is attractive. Based on the extrapolation of binaries and ternaries phase diagrams to higher levels the CALPHAD method gives an interesting approach of the formation and stability of potential phases in complex systems but needs accurate databases, i.e. reliable experimental results. The method is now widely used in the framework of the HEAs design [19,31,[35][36][37][38] and strategies based on CALPHAD and ab initio molecular dynamic calculations are proposed to accelerate the identification of single-phase solid solutions [39].
2.2. Electronic approach: from prediction to the strategy for ductilization of BCC high-entropy solid solutions

div.head: Predictive approach
div.p: Existing empirical criteria could not define sufficient conditions for the formation and stability of solid solutions. On the other hand, it is now accepted that criterion based on electronic considerations give interesting trends regarding the prediction of the crystal structure of such simple phases. Two parameters are generally involved in the case of HEAs, related to the number of electrons per atom of a system: (e/a) and the Valence electron concentration, VEC. The differences between the two criteria are subtle and came from the way the number of electrons is considered [40]. In the case of (e/a) only the number of itinerant electrons per atom at the Fermi level is involved whereas VEC includes those of the d-band. Whatever the chosen electronic parameter, both have long been indicators of the structural stability of phases, playing key roles particularly in ordering processes or in the prediction of metastable phase diagrams for some titanium alloys [41].

The introduction of an electronic criterion in HEAs based on VEC has been proposed by Guo et al. in 2011 [22]. The choice of VEC rather than (e/a) has been dictated by convenient reasons. In their pioneering work, the authors have studied the stability of FCC and BCC phases in the multicomponent CrCuFeNi 2 system with additions of aluminum [22]. They revealed that the evolution of the crystallographic nature of the formed phases with the addition of Al was clearly related to the VEC of the considered alloy. In that respect, alloys with VEC lower than 6.87 or higher than 8 seem to promote stable solid solution phases of BCC or FCC structures, respectively. The trend has never been underpinned by physical argumentation and the universality of the parameter for predicting the nature of crystallized phases in HEAs is thereby questionable, as only as cast materials were considered without any distinction between ordered or disordered structure [42]. In that way, Fig. 1 represents the evolution of the mixing enthalpy ΔH mix with VEC for > 360 alloy compositions for a qualitative purpose. Even if it could appear difficult, and not always relevant, to compare alloys at different equilibrium conditions (as cast, annealed…) attention is here focused on the qualitative aspects. On the one hand, as expected ΔH mix and VEC are not pertinent criteria allowing the differentiation between single and multiphase materials (Fig. 1a) [30]. On the other hand, BCC and FCC unique solid solutions appear in distinct zones following their VEC. Compositions based on elements of the IV, V and VI columns of the periodic table represent the great majority of the single BCC materials which seems basically reasonable: excepting polymorphs elements (Ti, Hf and Zr) all crystallize in the BCC structure; furthermore, the study of the binary phase diagrams between these elements give crucial information on the possible miscibility properties in the multi-component system. In that sense and from the 36 possible binary compositions, 26 present at least one domain of total miscibility at high temperatures i.e. close to the solidus. Zr, Hf and Cr are more likely to form intermetallics phases recalling the original idea developed by Otto et al. [29]: the more elements added in the system prone to form intermetallic phases with the others, the greater probability is obtaining complex microstructures a posteriori.

Plenty of BCC high-entropy solid solutions contain aluminum also (Fig. 1b). The addition of Al has been first introduced in 3d HEAs in the pioneer study of Yeh et al. [6] and is considered as a stabilizer of BCC phases which promotes the transition from FCC to BCC structure in HEAs. The situation is, however, more complex as BCC single phase HEAs were never observed in 3d based-HEAs with addition of Al. Al seems to promote ordering and the microstructures often consist of disordered BCC precipitates in an ordered B2 phase [43]. The high the Al content is, the more pronounced is its effect. Consequently, supposed BCC single-phase HEAs based on 3d elements with addition of Al will not be considered in this manuscript.

In refractory compositions, the introduction of Al was initially proposed to decrease the density of refractory HEAs as well [44] but also to study its impact on microstructures and mechanical properties [17,45]. Such impact of Al on the formation of BCC high-entropy solid solutions depends on the alloy composition and is well-known to form intermetallic compounds with Ti and other BCC elements. Some solid solutions are formed when Al is introduced in equimolar proportions as reported experimentally for AlCrMoXY (X = Ti [46], XY = NbTi [47], TiW [48], TiV [49]), AlMoTaTiV [50], AlNbTiXY (X = V [51], XY = TaV [44]).

div.head: Electronic approach for ductilization of BCC high-entropy solid solutions
div.p: The use of VEC has not been limited to the possible prediction of the structure of HEAs and in particular of BCC solid solutions. It has recently been introduced as a useful parameter to design ductile HEAs [52] but also to improve the combination of strength and ductility in AlCoCrFeNi x and CoCrCuFeMo x Ni systems [53]. Sheikh et al. developed a new ductile refractory BCC HEA, Hf 0.5 Nb 0.5 Ta 0.5 Ti 1.5 Zr, with the objective to achieve the intrinsic ductility [52], considering electron theory [54]. The strategy was to control alloy chemistry by decreasing the number of s + d valence electrons. The authors defined that the transition between brittle and ductile alloys depends on the VEC parameter with ductile behavior for alloy compositions with VEC < [8, 11, 13, 14, 17, 44-52, 55, 58-90]. Most of the values for FCC solid solutions and multi-phase materials are taken from supplementary material of [30]. ΔH mix has been calculated using Miedena's model and values found in [91]. Note that the mixing enthalpy is representative of the liquid state. Plain round and square (red and blue) illustrate alloys whose microstructure is made of one unique solid solution (round: BCC; square: FCC). Alloys with secondary phases are represented by (black) triangles; (b) Details of the BCC solid solution zone of the ΔH mix = f (VEC) diagram. Distinction is made for Al-free and Al-containing BCC compositions. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) 4.5.

Another strategy of alloy design has been recently proposed by Lilensten et al. to improve RT ductility of some BCC HEAs, exclusively based on titanium [55]. The electronic design strategy is close to that developed in conventional Ti alloys, and is related to the activation of specific deformation mechanisms (twinning, dislocation slip…) of Tibased compositions using cohesive strengths of chemical bonds between Ti and the alloying elements (Bo parameter) and the mean energy of d orbitals (Md parameter) [56,57]. By tuning the composition and properly choosing the added elements, it is possible to obtain metastable BCC solid solutions in the high-entropy composition space. The proof of concept has been evidenced in a non-equiatomic Hf-Nb-Ta-Ti-Zr composition with the appearance of a hardening phase (orthorhombic martensite) by TRansformation Induced Plasticity (TRIP) under stress. The same kind of strategy has been developed successively by Huang et al. in HfTa x TiZr alloys [58]. The idea was to decrease the content of Ta to destabilize the BCC solid solution. A composite structure with HCP and BCC phases were observed during straining of as cast (multiphase) HfTa x TiZr for x = 0.4, 0.5 and 0.6.

div.head: Processing routes
div.p: Recently, non-conventional processing of refractory HEAs based on powder metallurgy (PM) routes have been used as it is believed that PM route is as promising method for fabricating HEAs with high homogeneity and fine microstructures. The powders are usually pre-alloyed by mechanical milling (MM) to obtain the desired composition and ultrafine grain sizes. For instance, Kang et al. reported the fabrication of a single phase nanocrystalline BCC WNbMoTaV alloy by spark plasma sintering (SPS) which exhibited a large compressive yield strength [60] (see mechanical properties in Section 4). The difficulty of sintering refractory HEAs arises from the high melting points of the elemental components. In most cases a multiphase alloys is obtained along with a BCC phase [92].

Another drawback of PM-based routes is related to the powder quality and the amount that can be processed. One method of interest is self-propagating high-temperature synthesis (SHS). SHS is an attractive method for rapidly generating large quantities of materials (grams per second production rate). It has been demonstrated that during the reaction, a phenomenon of self-purification occurs and in some cases, impurities in the product were 2-7 times lower than in the original mixture [93]. Recently, nanometer-sized refractory powders in the Mo-Nb-W system have been synthesized by SHS [94,95]. Bulk BCC ternary and quaternary HEA compounds samples have been produced (MoNbW and MoNbWV, respectively) by SPS.

Hot isostatic pressing (HIP) has also been employed to process refractory HEAs, in combination with annealing [96] (see Supplementary material A) or following after casting for microstructure optimization. For instance, refractory equimolar HfNbTaTiZr alloys produced by vacuum arc-melting followed by HIPing showed predominantly a singlephase BCC structure [14].

As a growing modern metallurgy route, additive manufacturing (AM) is being considered for large scale processing of HEA bulk parts. This is a necessary step toward the use of bulk HEAs as structural materials, whatever their structure, FCC or BCC. This issue has been recently discussed by Gorsse et al. [97]. For instance, the Laser Engineered Net Shaping (LENS) synthesis resulted in a multiphase NbMoTiVZr HEA [98], while, the direct laser fabrication (DLF) used for the Al x CoCrFeNi system [99] yielded single phase BCC structures with increasing Al content, in line with microstructures that were processed by arc-melted counterparts [100][101][102]. Zhang et al. experimented fabrication of HEA parts by use of selective laser melting (SLM) process of MoNbTaW alloy from mixed powders [103]. It was shown that, unless improved by thermal-mechanical analysis and simulated experiment trials, uneven temperature distribution causes cracks within the fabricated part. Still, microstructure investigations demonstrated that only one BCC structure solid solution was formed in the alloy.

Finally, there are no specific techniques to be implemented for the development of BCC refractory HEAs. The same available conventional and/or non-conventional processes can be used with efficiency. However, due in part to their high melting points, the development of refractory HEAs with simple optimal microstructures is less obvious (see Section 2). This is particularly true for the case of PM-based processes. Nevertheless, it is believed that PM-base processes are likely to allow overcoming a technological leap, allowing the production of structures with complex shapes. This is a very promising field of investigation for materials scientists.

div.head: Mechanical properties
div.p: Along with hardness measurements, the majority of studies related to the mechanical behavior of HEAs, have been carried out under uniaxial loadings mostly with compression tests (Section 4.1). As potential structural materials, studies of HEAs behavior under large plastic deformation and severe plastic deformation conditions are of particular interest. It has been reported that, during subsequent annealing in the 500-800 °C range of HfNbTaTiZr solid solution in the as cast, cold rolled or severely deformed condition, the decomposition of the BCC phase occurred and NbTa or HfZr-rich second phases were formed [61,84,104,105]. Such instability of the BCC solid solution, if not controlled, makes it difficult to draw conclusions. Therefore, in the following description, we first will give a general view on the evolution of the mechanical properties of single phase BCC HEAs (Section 4.1). Sections 4.2 to 4.5 will focus on the mechanical behavior of BCC solid solutions under different loading conditions, including severe plastic deformation (Section 4.2), high strain rates (Section 4.3), fatigue and bending (Section 4.4), extrusion and rolling (Section 4.5).

div.head: Mechanical properties under simple uniaxial loadings
div.p: Almost all the single phase BCC solid solutions have been tested under compressive conditions. All the reported mechanical tests have been performed on compositions based on refractory elements of the IV, V and VI columns. Moreover it is worth noting that only 6 concentrated (single phase) BCC solid solutions have been tested in uniaxial tension at RT: HfNbTaTiZr [8,61,69,74,84], Hf 1.4 Nb 0.25 Ta 0.25 Ti 1.75 Zr 1.4 [55], Hf 0.5 Nb 0.5 Ta 0.5 Ti 1.5 Zr [52], Hf 0.4 Nb 1.54 Ta 1.54 Ti 0.89 Zr 0.64 [75], HfTaTiZr [58], HfNbTiZr [87].

Alike conventional BCC metals and alloys, the mechanical behavior of BCC compositionally complex solid solutions is strongly dependent on the temperature (Fig. 2a). Except for Hf 0.75 NbTa 0.5 Ti 1.5 Zr 1.25 reported by Podolskiy et al. [59] and tested down to cryogenic temperatures, mechanical properties of BCC HEAs have been studied between RT and 1600 °C for the majority of refractory compositions. BCC solid solutions retain yield stresses superior to 500 MPa up to 600 °C. Mechanical properties decrease more or less strongly beyond 600 °C and a large range of yield stresses is observed at 800, 1000 and 1200 °C. Under extreme temperatures (> 1200 °C) only MoNbTaW and MoN-bTaVW maintain incredible strengths (405 and 477 MPa at 1600 °C for MoNbTaW and MoNbTaVW, respectively). The gaps are growing between the different BCC HEAs if one considers the specific strength (Fig. 2b). At room temperature Al 0.3 NbTa 0.8 Ti 1.4 V 0.2 Zr 1.3 possess the most interesting value with ~255 MPa•cm 3 •g -1 [45]. In the 400-800 °C range, the highest specific yield stresses are obtained for annealed lowdensity AlCrMoTi and AlCrMoNbTi alloys with values ranging between ~130 and ~180 MPa•cm 3 •g -1 [46,47]. Beyond 800 °C specific strength drops down for the vast majority of the solid solutions.

The behavior of the thermo-mechanically processed H 0.75 NbTa 0.5 Ti 1.5 Zr 1.25 in the low temperature regime (T < RT) displays a strong increase in the yield stress which testifies of the thermally activated nature of the deformation process for such BCC materials. The alloy maintains a good compressive ductility down to -196 °C (77 K) and a brittle behavior is observed at -269 °C (4.2 K) with the emergence of serrations probably due to the activation of twinning [59].

Unsurprisingly, the mechanical properties of BCC HEAs cover a broad spectrum of yield stress at RT. The large disparity of values is related to the great number of tested alloys which, in the vast majority are in the as-solidified condition i.e. with non-optimized microstructures. The lowest yield stress value (540 MPa) is obtained for the TRIP HEA with Hf 1.4 Nb 0.25 Ta 0.25 Ti 1.75 Zr 1.4 composition [55]. In this case a fully BCC recrystallized microstructure has been tested in uniaxial tension and the appearance of a stress-induced martensite enables to achieve a strong work-hardening rate of 3 GPa (0.103 if normalized by shear modulus) and an interesting tensile ductility as high as 23%.

The same trend is observed in the HfTa x TiZr (yield stresses of ~400, ~700 and ~800 MPa for x = 0.4, 0.5 and 0.6, respectively) but starting from a duplex microstructure of BCC + HCP phases [58]. The optimization of an initial fully BCC microstructure should probably lead to improved mechanical properties.

The most attractive behavior at RT is obtained with the refractory MoNbTaVW composition prepared by MA and SPS with grains of nanometers size, while keeping a limited but reasonable plastic deformation of 8.8% [60] (Fig. 2a). Apart from the contribution of grain boundaries, solid solution and interstitial strengthening effects seem to play a key role in the outstanding compressive properties of this bulk densified MoNbTaVW alloy.

Solid solutions could also attain yield stresses much higher than 1 GPa but mostly but with a reduced ductility. This is especially the case for cast MoNbTaVW and MoNbTaW HEAs [81], HfTaTiZr [58] and also for alloys with high aluminum and/or high molybdenum content often displaying brittle behavior (Fig. 3) [17,47,49,64,66,77,79,88]. Nevertheless it appears that the weakening effect associated to Al is not so obvious particularly in the case of as-cast Al x NbTaTiV compositions [44]. Whatever the value of x (0.25 < x < 1), compressive ductility does not seem to be affected by Al and fracture has not been reported even up to 50% of strain. The same trend is evidenced with the addition of Al or Mo in the ductile HfNbTaTiZr solid solution [65,66]. Actually, Al and Mo additions up to 13 at.% allow a significant increase of the compressive stress without causing brittle fracture at RT [65,66]. Solid solution strengthening is proposed to explain the increase of the yield strength which increases linearly with the Al or Mo concentration [65]. Surprisingly the relative effect of Mo on the RT strength of HfNbTaTiZr is similar to that of Mo additions in Nb alloys [106]. In BCC HEAs the strengthening effect is experienced up to 1200 °C as revealed in HfMoTaTiZr, HfMoNbTiZr and in HfMoNbTaTiZr. Between 800 and 1200 °C those solid solutions retain interesting compressive mechanical properties and deform over 30% beyond 1000 °C despite the appearance of Mo-rich and (Zr, Hf)-rich precipitates during testing at 1000 °C and 1200 °C for HfMoTaTiZr and HfMoNbTaTiZr, respectively [64,107].

Ductile BCC solid solutions have been extensively proposed in literature especially for compositions close to the quinary HfNbTaTiZr alloy [14]. Initially designed by Senkov et al. by introducing such as Ti and Zr in order to decrease the density of brittle MoNbTaVW and MoNbTaW alloys and improve the ductility at RT, this composition has been used as a basis for the development of numerous other single and multi-phase HEAs. The HfNbTaTiZr alloy is actually the sole equiatomic BCC solid solution whose microstructure (grain size) could be easily controlled by cold rolling and subsequent annealing [8,74,84,108]. It also displays a good tensile ductility as high as 15% in well-recrystallized samples [74]. RT compressive yield stress of HfNbTaTiZr falls in the range of 890-1073 MPa [65,66,68,73], and in the 800-830 MPa range in tensile loading [69] in the as-solidified condition. The solid solution keeps solid mechanical properties up to 400 °C (yield stress of 790 MPa). The decrease of the yield stress is more pronounced from 600 °C (535 MPa) and falls below 100 MPa at 1200 °C [83].

div.head: Severe plastic deformation
div.p: Severe plastic deformation (SPD) has been used to test and/or to further transform as-processed HEAs. For instance, Schuh et al. [61] subjected an equiatomic, single-phase HfNbTaTiZr high-entropy alloy to high-pressure torsion. The process yielded an alloy having a grain size below 100 nm. The hardness increases from 420 HV1 for the asprocessed state to 530 HV1 for an annealing temperature of 500 °C, while for temperatures of 700 °C and higher a softening compared to the as-processed state occurred. Similarly, in the case of BCC AlNbTiV alloy deformed by high pressure torsion, a nanocrystalline microstructure was induced whose hardness increased from ~7.4 GPa for the as-processed alloy to ~10.4 GPa after annealing at 700 °C [109]. But for higher temperatures the hardness decreased. It was suggested that the unusual annealing response was related to the formation of intermetallic phases creating a multi-phase nanocomposite material during annealing. These results raise once again concerns about high temperature microstructure stability during a "dynamic" or in-situ condition. Nevertheless, they are indicative for future research directions aimed at understanding the long-term utilization of BCC HEAs upon loading at high temperature [19].

div.head: High strain rate and dynamic behavior
div.p: Mechanical properties of high-entropy BCC solid solutions are sensitive to the strain rate. The strain rate dependence of the yield stress has been studied in HfNbTaTiZr at 800 °C [83] and in HfMoNbTiZr between 800 and 1200 °C [107]. The presence of two regimes has been revealed in HfNbTaTiZr with a strong dependence of the yield strength in the 10 -5 -3.10 -4 s -1 range with a significant increase of the stress with strain rate in that range followed by much more moderate increase up to 10 -1 s -1 . Fine analysis of the dependence has led to conclusion that involved mechanisms are diffusion controlled. An activation energy of 226 kJ•mol -1 has been proposed for the phenomenon [83].

The effect of the strain rate on the mechanical behavior of equimolar HfNbTaTiZr HEA was studied in the strain rate range of ~10 -3 s -1 -3.4 × 10 3 s -1 by Dirras et al. [68]. Fig. 4 show typical examples of the true stress-true plastic strain plots for selected strain rates to illustrate the behavior. As in the case of many conventional BCC alloys, a quasi-linear work hardening is observed for the low strain rate regime, while a strong softening occurs in the dynamic strain rate domain, which was associated with the formation of adiabatic shear bands (ASBs). Fig. 5 shows the flow stress versus the logarithm of the strain rate for the as-cast HfNbTaTiZr alloy. Two regimes with different index sensitivity of the flow stress can be seen, corresponding to so-called thermally activated (lower index) and "viscous" drag (higher index) regime, respectively. While the yield strength (or flow stress) increased moderately with increasing the strain rate within the thermally activated regime, the increase in strength becomes faster for the strain rates between ~10 3 and ~3.4 × 10 3 s -1 in the dynamic regime. Indeed, the strength at 3.4 × 10 3 s -1 was about 40% higher than that measured at the strain rate of ~10 -3 s . In conventional alloys the transition from thermally activated dislocation mechanisms to viscous drag is still controversial. For FCC materials, it was shown that both thermally activated and viscous drag mechanisms may be operative within the high strain rates range [110]. In other reports [111,112], it was suggested that the plastic deformation at a very high strain rate of 10 4 s -1 is still controlled by the thermally activated dislocation mechanism and the upturn of the flow stress is caused by the acceleration of dislocation Fig. 5. Stress-strain plot (yield stress and flow stress at 0.05 offset) for the ascast HfNbTaTiZr showing a sharp upturn characteristic of the transition from thermally activated (low strain rates) to viscous drag (high strain rates) regimes [68].

generation, leading to an abrupt increase of dislocation density which results in a reduced spacing between gliding obstacles. In the case of BCC HEAs, investigations are still to be carried out. EBSD investigations of dynamic compression loaded as-cast HfNbTaTiZr alloy revealed a strong strain localization due to the formation of ASBs, which caused the early softening observed during dynamic compression (Fig. 6). It has to be noted that Zhang et al. [113] reported on the dynamic deformation behaviors and constitutive relations of an AlCoCr 1.5 Fe 1.5 NiTi 0.5 high-entropy alloy with dual-phase body-centered cubic structure. The alloy exhibited excellent compression strength and large plasticity upon quasi-static and dynamic loadings. In particular, under high-speed dynamic loadings, the yield strength increases with increasing the strain rate, and significant dynamic strain-rate sensitivity is obtained. Contrariwise to the work by Dirras et al. no adiabatic shear bands were observed [68]. The contrasting behavior could be explained by the competition between the dislocation drag mechanisms and thermal activation dislocation generation.

div.head: Fatigue Properties and fracture by bending tests
div.p: As discussed in the previous sections, HEAs have so far demonstrated interesting room temperature mechanical behaviors. For structural materials, availability of fatigue data (among others) is essential. Unfortunately, unlike FCC HEA counterparts [114] such data for single phase refractory BCC HEAs are scarce. To address such a paucity, in our group, equimolar HfNbTaTiZr HEA was subjected to four points bending loading fatigue tests at a stress ratio of 0.1. As shown in Fig. S1 and S2 (see Supplementary material B) while keeping a limited data scatter in the S-N plot, a fatigue ratio of 0.43, is found, which is an outstanding level, significantly higher than comparable data from other metallic materials available at the moment. Fracture surface analysis showed that intergranular fatigue cracks initiation mechanism takes place at specimens' surface (Fig. 7).

Recently, Zou et al. studied the fracture of a refractory HEA using in situ micro-cantilever tests [115]. The report shows that the fracture toughness of a bi-crystalline MoNbTaW HEA was one order of magnitude lower than that of single crystalline ones. Atom probe tomography of the bi-crystal HEA reveals element segregation and formation of oxides and nitrides at grain boundaries, suggesting that minimizing grain boundary segregation is critical to improving fracture properties in refractory BCC HEAs.

div.head: Extrusion and rolling
div.p: The first successful attempt to cold roll a HEA with a BCC crystal structure has been reported by Senkov and Semiatin [84] on the single phase alloy HfNbTaTiZr that was successfully rolled at RT up to 86.4% reduction in thickness. Extensive grain elongation, formation of deformation bands within the grains, and development of crystallographic textures were the main features observed, depending on the rolling reduction amount. A true tensile stress of 1295 MPa and tensile ductility of 4.7% was reported for the sheet that was strained to 86.4% thickness reduction. After annealing at about 1000 °C, a slight reduction of the true tensile stress from 1295 MPa to 1262 MPa was reported and was accompanied by tensile ductility of 9.7% as a consequence of dynamic recrystallization. Recently, Eleti et al. presented a detailed study on the formation and evolution of grain growth textures of equimolar HfNbTaTiZr HEA, by cold rolling at medium (50%) and heavy (90%) deformation levels, respectively, in the as-deformed and annealed states [108]. It was shown that deformation heterogeneity significantly influenced the formation of cold-rolling and annealing textures.

Finally, the mechanical properties of BCC HEAs have been studied using various loading conditions, from quasi-static to dynamic loadings, controlled/limited to large plastic deformations. In many cases, the as processed microstructures are annealed to ensure chemical homogeneity [97]. The general trends are high hardness and high strength in compression loading [97] along with a strong work hardening [60] which vanishes when a true stress/true strain curve is considered [74]. It is therefore important to investigate the underlying deformation mechanisms and correlate them to the observed macroscopic behavior, and, more importantly, to try to figure out what makes HEAs so different (if any) compared to conventional alloys. This is the objective of the next section.

div.head: Deformation mechanisms
div.p: Actually, in-depth studies of the impact of the concentrated solid solution on the plastic properties and associated deformation mechanisms are rare in BCC HEAs [31]. In alloys containing 3d-based transition Fig. 6. EBSD IPF maps of HfNbTaTiZr specimens deformed in the thermally activated regime (a) and viscous regime (b). While the thermally activated show mostly deformation bands, the viscous drag regime is characterized by adiabatic shear bands with various widths (two of them are marked by white arrows) [68]. elements, the sole study dedicated to deformation mechanisms in non-FCC structure has been conducted by Feuerbacher in Al 1.68 Co 1.2 Cr 0.66 Fe 0.9 Ni 1.56 with single ordered B2 phase [116].

The study of such deformation mechanisms is, however, a key point particularly in understanding of mechanical properties. Reports devoted to this aspect have been mainly conducted in refractory (dense) ductile HEAs based on quinary systems with Ti, Zr, Hf, Nb and/or Ta. Those alloys are generally well suited for investigations of the plastic deformation due to: i) their inherent ductility particularly at room temperature and, ii) the ease with which it is possible to obtain homogenized samples with controlled grain size. Actually, mechanisms have been discussed in three compositions: the equiatomic HfNbTaTiZr [14,73,74,83,117] and the non-equiatomic Hf 0.4 Nb 1.54 Ta 1.54 Ti 0.89 Zr 0.64 [75] and H 0.75 NbTa 0.5 Ti 1.5 Zr 1.25 [59].

The (experimental) analysis of associated deformation mechanisms have been extensively performed in the equiatomic HfNbTaTiZr composition being submitted to various mechanical loadings in quasi-static, simple shear or dynamic conditions, mainly at RT [14,68,73,74,83,117]. Solid solution strengthening has been assumed to explain the observed high strength with a high contribution of modulus effects [14].

On the basis of current knowledge and from the observations of (ascast or recrystallized) samples strained in compression or in uniaxial tension for a broad range of deformation levels, the main features could be summarized as follows, for quasi-static conditions:

-Screw dislocations with Burgers vector parallel to the 〈111〉 directions are identified and control the plastic deformation of the HfNbTaTiZr solid solution [73,74] (Fig. 8). Same type of 〈111〉 dislocations has been observed by Feuerbacher et al. in a derived NbTa-rich composition [75]; -Screw dislocations often appear straight and are of reduced mobility [74]; -Dislocation debris (loops, dipoles) are highlighted suggesting some pinning effect in the material, mainly ascribed to a solid solution effect.

The evolution of work-hardening rate of HfNbTaTiZr is conventional for BCC structures with an initial sharp decrease followed by a constant stage until Considere's criteria and the resulting plastic instability. The microstructure has been associated with the glide of rectilinear screw dislocations then their heterogeneous patterning in bands in the very first stages of plastic deformation [73,74]. The results suggest high Peierls stresses exerted on screw dislocations due to nonplanar character of their core. In addition, specific core properties are expected with non-Schmid effects and observations of glide on {112} planes [74]. Strained microstructures are of composite nature and simultaneously contain a high density of defects in localized bands and dislocation-free zones which enable kinematic hardening [74]. Shortrange interactions play a key role in the mechanical behavior of such complex solid solution at room temperature as highlighted by joint measurement of physical activation volumes close to 40 b 3 and effective shear stress representing between 80 and 90% of the maximum shear stress. Care must be taken considering activation volumes as they are significant if one type of obstacles monitor the deformation rate. Consequently the interpretation of the values must be carefully conducted as measured volumes are often apparent and could account for several active mechanisms during the deformation process [118]. It therefore seems wiser to discuss evolution of the parameter with temperature to follow possible tendencies.

In that sense obtained (strain-independent) values of 40 b 3 by Lilensten et al. in their study of the HfNbTaTiZr solid solution tested in uniaxial direction at RT do not appear compatible with a pure Peierls mechanism for which the controlling mechanism is the nucleation of double kink pair. Due to the presence of loops and dipoles in the deformed microstructures, and based on studies in dilute iron based alloys [119], a pinning mechanism is proposed by the authors. Such an effect supposes a strong interaction between lateral kinks and solute atoms/ fluctuations of local composition leading to the formation of superjogs which are considered as strong barriers for slip. The pinning mechanism is also in line with recent modeling of the plastic properties of a BCC model solid solution [120]. In their simulations, Rao et al. have cleverly analyzed the dislocation properties in two distinct cases: the BCC solid solution is disordered with randomly distributed elements on the lattice and disordered with atoms owning the mean properties of the alloy. Whereas the latter behaves like a conventional BCC alloy, the situation is quite different in the random one. Activation energy for double kink pair mechanism is considerably increased and strengthening is associated to compositional fluctuations thus modifying the screw dislocation core along the line [120]. Superjogs are formed as a consequence of the pinning effects during the motion of screw dislocations and numerous debris are observed. Interestingly and contrariwise to classical BCC metals and alloys, edge dislocations are hardly mobile and require a high critical resolved shear stress to move.

Considering the high dependency of the mechanical behavior of BCC structures with temperature, the analysis of the activation parameters is crucial for the identification of rate-controlling mechanism. In that way, the recent study of a ductile BCC H 0.75 NbTa 0.5 Ti 1.5 Zr 1.25 solid solution is the sole and unique report and deals with the low temperature regime i.e. from 4.2 to 350 K [59]. By compression testing and flow stress sensitivity measurements on cold rolled material, Podolskiy et al. provide a complete view of the mechanical behavior in the low temperature regime. As expected the yield stress is increasing with decreasing temperature and serrations are observed only at 4.2 K suggesting the possible activation of twinning. A similar aspect of the compressive curves is evidenced between 77 and 350 K, which seems to be indirectly related to the presence of one active deformation mechanism as argued by the authors. Strain rate sensitivity reaches its greatest magnitude between 120 and 170 K and apparent activation volumes computed at 2% of plastic strain are ranged from 5 to 50 b 3 between 4. obtained an activation enthalpy close to 1 eV from RT to 100 °C and a slightly highest value of 1.8 eV at 200 °C. In that study activation volumes were found to be stress dependent and between 24 and 94 b 3 .

In the Podolskiy's study, the hypothesis of the presence of atomic clusters has been excluded despite the reasonable fit with the experimental results [59]. Using simplified calculations of the average distance between possible clusters in the slip plane of dislocations, a value of 1.8 nm has been found and seems hardly compatible with the deformation process in the authors' view. Two points have to be mentioned: first the model used to describe the contribution of possible clusters is oversimplified, based on empirical parameters; secondly, authors have presented no experimental observations related to strained microstructure to support such assumption. In that sense, only observations of dislocation dynamics during in-situ TEM testing could provide reliable information on the dislocation motion and associated barriers in such compositionally complex solid solutions.

In dynamic conditions, i.e. for strain rates higher than 1 s -1 , intense slip activity and/or macroscopic band shearing are evidenced in the as solidified HfNbTaTiZr solid solution [68]. At a strain rate of 4.53 s -1 , deformation is heterogeneous in the grains and localized in wavy bands for which lattice rotations are intense. Similar observations have been performed by Senkov and Semiatin in cold-rolled HfNbTaTiZr material with 65% of thickness reduction [84]. At higher strain rates, flow stress follows the classical Taylor equation suggesting that the increase of stress is related to the increase of dislocation density, at least at the beginning of that regime. Post-mortem investigation shows large macroscopic (adiabatic) shear bands which ultimately lead to the failure of the specimen. The heterogeneities of deformation are evidenced right through especially at grain boundaries which seem to be accommodated by kink banding. No twinning has been reported contrary to conventional (refractory) BCC structures [121].

div.head: Critical review and prospects
div.p: The development of BCC HEAs uses both conventional and nonconventional techniques. The most widely used and most developed fabrication technique is casting which, when followed by heat treatments, lead to homogeneous and stable microstructures ideal for the study of the mechanical properties. However, this technique produces a limited volume of materials. The implementation of other processing methods is necessary, for example for practical application at industrial scale. Still, the description that was given above show that for complex shapes and large-scale production, the versatility of powder metallurgy processes can quickly become a solution to implement. Nevertheless, this technique is currently hindered by the quality of the powders and the homogeneity of the mixtures for BCC HEAs.

The description given in the preceding sections has also shown that the mechanical properties have been studied over a wide range of temperatures, from the cryogenic to extreme ones. In general, and with the exception of brittle compositions, BCC high-entropy solid solutions retain high mechanical strengths and reasonable ductility. However, it should be pointed out that the data acquisition conditions in most mechanical tests are not always known and deformations are usually measured without extensometers. The collected experimental data do not make it possible in most cases to measure some basic but necessary elastic parameters such as the Young's or shear modulus. Furthermore, the curves (for the case of compression testing) presented are generally nominal data from which significant strain hardening rate is observed. However, when true stress vs true strain representations are considered, the previous strain hardening rate vanishes or at best is only light. Therefore, in general, one should be cautious when making comparisons.

Few studies exist for the study of mechanical properties below the ambient for BCC HEAs, except that of Podolskiy et al. on the grade Hf 0.75 NbTa 0.5 Ti 1.5 Zr 1.25 [59]. This may be related to the difficulty of making such experiments. From a fundamental point of view, such studies are of some importance as they could access to quantities related to the thermally activated mechanisms of the plastic deformation. In the same vein, a deeper and broader analysis of deformation mechanisms is essential to better approach the evolution of mechanical properties in the whole range of temperature. In particularand even some efforts have been realized recently from the experimental and modeling points of viewmechanisms of dislocation mobility in such complex solid solutions is still an open question. Actual experimental observations of deformation mechanisms have given important information on defects but are limited to the RT mechanical behavior. Future studies could be focused on the identification of mechanisms by the reliable description of strained microstructures, especially for T > 20 °C. The approach could also be similar to what has been already and successfully performed in FCC equiatomic solid solutions [122].

High temperature tests are inherently interesting for BCC HEAs and Fig. 2b clearly demonstrate the huge potential of such materials for high temperature structural applications. A lot of work on this aspect has been carried so far and valuable data have been obtained. However, almost all of these tests carried out under a controlled atmosphere which raises the question as to the mechanical behavior of these alloys in real conditions (corrosive environment, exposure to air [48,123]…). In addition, and taking into account that microstructure evolution during tests of the microstructureinherently dependent of the solid solution stabilityis often reported, real situation evaluation in severe conditions is still to be executed.

In general, whether it concerns the results coming from the fabrication (see above) or the study of the macroscopic mechanical behavior of HEAs, the comparison between data coming from different studies remains rather delicate and quickly becomes very approximate: even if the process of elaboration remains the same in most cases, i.e., casting, the generated microstructures (grain sizes, crystallographic textures, etc.) following post-processing via heat treatments are often not comparable, as well as the experimental conditions of the tests involved (compression, traction, hardness, strain rate, …). Therefore, data compilation from different investigations and sources quickly appears to be difficult and needing to be treated carefully. Nevertheless, the use of such compilation is of interest only to the census of available data, but does not allow conclusions to be drawn.

Those previous critical aspects should not hide the interesting prospects in the study and the development of high-performance HEAs with BCC based-structure. The actual analysis of the mechanical properties of BCC high-entropy solid solutions show an interesting behavior up to 800 °C. Beyond 800 °C, and apart from dense compositions, few alloys maintain high strength. A possible improvement of high temperature mechanical properties will be to introduce coherent precipitation in disordered BCC matrix. Signs of such a way have been proposed a long time ago by Naka, but in a different context and on the basis of intermetallic compounds [124][125][126]. Recent effort allow to be optimistic with the development of refractory high-entropy superalloys based on Al, Mo, Nb, Ta, Ti and Zr with B2 + BCC structures [82,127]. Exceptional compressive mechanical properties are achieved up to 1000 °C and attempts have to be made to improve the behavior beyond 1200 °C. Optimization of alloy and microstructure design, particularly by thermo-mechanical treatments are critical steps, in this direction.

At RT the situation is quite different with a broad range of mechanical properties. Many BCC high-entropy solid solutions suffer from a lack of ductility and display a poor strain hardening. The strategy leading to the design of BCC HEAs with enhanced work hardening rate and improved ductility is promising. In particular and following the example of diluted titanium alloys, the use of the BCC phase metastability seems efficient in concentrated systems and needs further attention.

div.head: Concluding remarks
div.p: The new metallurgy concept based on HEA is a colossal opportunity to develop new metallic alloys with properties yet to be discovered. Many compositions are emerging globally and in several research laboratories and groups worldwide. Among all the proposed solutions, single phase (disordered) BCC HEAs are particularly interesting and generally display significant mechanical behavior up to 800 °C. BCC HEAs position themselves as credible material solutions for high-temperature structural applications. If compared to steels, titanium alloys or superalloys, the HEA concept is new and an incredible development has been realized in past 10 years. This must lead to an optimistic vision of future material solutions but this should also lead the community to ask questions about future strategy. The field is clearly attractive but it should not lead us to forget the answers and the challenges we still have to face. This is necessary if we want to give visibility to this new area and possibly trigger some interest from industrial partners. This is also a necessary step, as it was done for other materials of large diffusion, for instance in the case of superalloys for the aerospace industry.
To this end, some non-exhaustive questions are listed below:

• Based on the inherent idea of the concept, numerous compositions are developed. Some allow real optimization, with properties (mainly mechanical for BCC alloys) measured in a systematic and complete way. Is it necessary for establishing the HEA's domain, to elaborate so many compositions without characterizing them completely?

• For some applications, there is a dramatic lack of some physical and important data, such as elastic constants, diffusion coefficients, heat capacity, resistivity, etc. Should not we encourage such kinds of investigations?

• Designing HEAs for high temperature applications is challenging and recent reviews have shown that they can compete with Ni-base alloys for instance. Should not HEA also be tested (from the mechanical point of view) in real-world conditions, in air and in harsh environments for example, as we pretend to use them in such conditions?

• The few studies available on tracking deformation mechanisms have shown, for the moment almost similar characteristics (dislocation patterning, slip plane, stress partitioning, etc.) with conventional materials, with a few exceptions. Do we have tools to probe this new class of materials more finely? Should we develop indirect methods, based for example on physical parameters?

figure.head: Fig. 1 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 1. (a) Relationship between mixing enthalpy (ΔH mix ) and valence electron concentration (VEC) for 358 alloy compositions. Disordered single BCC solid solutions are found in the following references:[8, 11, 13, 14, 17, 44-52, 55, 58-90]. Most of the values for FCC solid solutions and multi-phase materials are taken from supplementary material of[30]. ΔH mix has been calculated using Miedena's model and values found in[91]. Note that the mixing enthalpy is representative of the liquid state. Plain round and square (red and blue) illustrate alloys whose microstructure is made of one unique solid solution (round: BCC; square: FCC). Alloys with secondary phases are represented by (black) triangles; (b) Details of the BCC solid solution zone of the ΔH mix = f (VEC) diagram. Distinction is made for Al-free and Al-containing BCC compositions. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)

figure.head: Fig. 2 .
figure.figDesc: Fig.2. Evolution of the yield stress (a) and of the specific yield stress (based on the theoretical density for each composition) (b) with temperature for all BCC single phase HEAs with equi-or near-equiatomic compositions (with disordered structure), and for strain rates lower or equal to 10 -3 s -1 (nc = nanocrystalline). Results have been distinguished following their thermal history. 193 mechanical tests are reported in the figure, on the basis of the results obtained for 70 BCC single-phase HEAs ([96]; see Supplementary material A).

figure.head: 4 4 Fig. 3 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 3. Influence of Al and/or Mo additions on the evolution of the yield stress with temperature for BCC single-phase HEAs. Arrows indicate the effect of Al and/or Mo additions on the yield stress for some Hf-Nb-Ta-Ti-Zr solid solutions. Data collected from [8, 11, 14, 17, 45, 55, 58, 59, 61, 64-66, 68, 69, 73-75, 79, 80, 82-85, 87].

figure.head: Fig. 4 .
figure.figDesc: Fig.4. Illustration of the evolution of the macroscopic mechanical behavior of as-cast HfNbTaTiZr alloy as a function of the strain rate at RT. Compression tests at velocities above 10 m•s -1 were performed by direct impact loading[68].

figure.head: Fig. 7 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 7. An example of a fracture surface of HfNbTaTiZr (recrystallized microstructure) after four points bending fatigue test (σ max ′ = 965 MPa, N f = 1,621,220 cycles). A crack propagation zone (possibly transgranular) is identified on the top left (indicated by a white arrow). A final rupture zone is shown at the right bottom which shows shallow dimples as found in previous tensile tests on as-cast microstructure [69]. The inset at the top right correspond to the initiation zone on the top left.

2 and 350 K. Experimental results have been fitted by models used in the formalism of thermally activated deformation of BCC alloys considering two types of barriers for dislocation motion: Peierls and local clusters of atoms. In the case of the Peierls barriers two regimes are considered and are described by the line tension model for high effective stresses and elastic interactions between well-formed kinks for low effective stresses. The authors are leaning toward the Peierls model with obtained activation energies of 0.69 and 0.84 eV in the low and high temperature regimes, respectively, in good agreement with values for classical BCC metals for kink pair nucleation. The same order of magnitude has been evidenced in the Hf 0.4 Nb 1.54 Ta 1.54 Ti 0.89 Zr 0.64 alloy [75]. With temperature cycling experiments, Feuerbacher et al. has

figure.head: Fig. 8 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 8. Bright field micrograph (inset: diffraction vector g = 110) of screw dislocations with b = a/2 〈111〉 in strained HfNbTaTiZr solid solution (tensile test on recrystallized material, total deformation ε T = 1.4%).

div.p: Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https:// doi.org/10.1016/j.matchar.2018.07.015.
